repnme.cdata!:
Chad - The First, Second, and Third
            Structural Adjustment Credit Projects

abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is rated
            satisfactory with project sustainability as likely. Both
            World Bank and Borrower performances are adjudged
            satisfactory. The three Structural Adjustment Credits were
            fully consistent with the 1996 Country Assistance Strategy.
            But the new approach proposed in the 1996 CAS, consisting of
            moving towards joint funding by the donor community and the
            Government of a public expenditure program, was too
            ambitious in a post-conflict situation with this
            government's limited capacity and track record. The
            proposal for single-tranche adjustment credits tied with the
            budget cycle was appropriate given the circumstances. But
            the second and third credits should have been better
            anchored in public expenditure reviews carried out jointly
            with the donor community. Through the divestiture program
            process, the government gained useful experience and is more
            equipped to handle large privatizations. The technical and
            steering committees established for the reform program and
            its components helped establish a consensus among
            stakeholders in Chad; the top government officials were kept
            adequately informed and were able to make required
            decisions. Little progress was made during program
            implementation in the areas of civil service reform,
            reinsertion of demobilized soldiers, and cotton sector
            reform because these areas were highly sensitive politically.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Structural Adjustment Program
            Project aims to: 1) restore the state's capacity to
            govern (including creating an environment of security and
            enforceable contracts); 2) enable the administration to
            function (provide essential public services and pay for
            them); and 3) facilitate the operation of the private
            sector. The latter includes pursuit of the ongoing program
            of state enterprise divestiture and financial system reform,
            as well as the initiation of the reform of the cotton
            sector. Specific objectives include: 1) keeping the civil
            service working while it is reformed to make it more
            effective; 2) demobilizing a significant number of soldiers
            who would settle in active, civilian economic life; 3)
            restructuring expenditures; and 4) increasing the share
            allocated to essential development services such as primary
            education, health and public basic support to private sector activities.
